results.title: Digging up ancestors
results.brief_description: Investigates the discovery of extensive fossil beds at Koonwarra, Victoria. The beds are estimated to be around 120 million years old. Professor Jim Warren, an expert in fossil research, discusses his work at the beds and demonstrates how much information fossils can give us. Suitable for early secondary levels. Narrated by John Gaden.

results.title: Diggers
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan, Don Scheldrup and Australia. Dept. of Defence. Public Relations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sentinel”.
Despite the advanced state of military technology it is still the “Digger” who determines the success or otherwise of the Australian Army. It is the infantry soldier who must find the enemy, capture his territory and fight him at close quarters.

results.title: Digestion: Muscular and mechanical movement
results.creator_credit: Frank Wells, Gaumont-British Instructional and Beryl Denman Lacey
results.brief_description: Deals with the muscular processes involved in the digestion of food. The film demonstrates mechanical and muscular processes of mastication and swallowing; peristalsis in the oesophagus, small intestine, and colour segmentation in the small intestine; contraction waves in the cardiac and pyloric regions of the stomach; absorption of food into the blood from the small intestine, and of water and salts from the colon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Wells, Gaumont-British Instructional and Beryl Denman Lacey

results.title: Digestion. Pt. 2: chemical changes
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and Beryl Denman Lacey
results.brief_description: An account of the chief changes involved in the chemical breakdown of the main types of foodstuffs during digestion. Shows the secretion of saliva and its action on cooked starch; the gastric glands; secretion of intestinal bile and pancreatic juice and their effect on proteins, carbohydrates and fats; the absorption of nutriment through the villi and lacteals into the blood and its subsequent circulation through the body.

results.title: Digestion of food
results.brief_description: A summary of the digestive process, including the following aspects: the function of the mouth; stomach, and small intestine; secretions and enzymes - the systems affected and the products formed; reactions, digestive movements, and their control (recorded by microphotography); the relation of the circulatory and nervous systems to the digestive process; motility of the digestive tract - normal movements, hypermotility, inhibition, hunger contractions, segmentations, peristalsis and anti-peristalsis; and motility of the intestinal villi.

results.title: Digestion in our bodies
results.brief_description: The steps in the digestive process and the functions of the main organs. How and why food must be digested before the body can use it. Why correct eating attitudes and habits are important. Uses X-ray techniques and simple diagrams.

results.title: Dig a million, make a million
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Tom Haydon
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the financing and business organisation behind the development of the Mount Tom Price iron mine and the associated industry. Shows the role of overseas capital and enterprise in the exploitation of the resources.

results.title: Diffusion and osmosis
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A study of diffusion as it takes place in living cells. Uses photomicrography, time-lapse photography, simple laboratory demonstrations, and models to explain diffusion and to clarify how a selectively permeable membrane functions. Demonstrates osmosis, the diffusion of water through a selectively permeable membrane, and includes practical examples of diffusion and osmosis.
